p: In primary treatment, MECD repressed the intestinal travel of charcoal meal at all the treated dosages. The investigation revealed that the rate of gastrointestinal travel of charcoal was decreased with the elevation of test doses respectively. The data revealed that the percentage reduction of gastrointestinal transit of charcoal was 12.21 % ( p < 0.05), 34.77 % ( p < 0.01) 49.40 % ( p < 0.001) and 76.10% ( p < 0.001)), at doses of 50 mg/kg, 100 mg/kg, 200 mg/kg, and 400 mg/kg, respectively. The maximum dose of this extract showed comparable anti-motility effects to that of the standard drug (78.83%, p < 0.05). All the revealed data were calculated with the comparison of control (1% Tween-80). Besides the percent of inhibition of MECD, the total length of the small intestine, distance moved by the charcoal in the small intestine and peristaltic index (%) were also calculated. All the findings have been listed in Table 4.
